message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: VITAMIN: A Compositional Framework for Model Checking of Multi-Agent Systems
Paper Abstract: The verification of Multi-Agent Systems (MAS) poses a significant challenge. Various approaches and methodologies exist to address this challenge; however, tools that support them are not always readily avail able. Even when such tools are accessible, they tend to be hard-coded, lacking in compositionality, and challenging to use due to a steep learning curve. In this paper, we introduce a methodology designed for the formal verification of MAS in a modular and versatile manner, along with an initial prototype, that we named VITAMIN. Unlike existing verification methodologies and frameworks for MAS, VITAMIN is constructed for easy extension to accommodate various logics (for specifying the properties to verify) and models (for deter mining on what to verify such properties).
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Web search results for query: "Model checking"

Links: [{"title":"Model checking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model_checking"},{"title":"Abstract model checking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abstract_model_checking"},{"title":"List of model checking tools - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_model_checking_tools"},{"title":"Clock (model checking) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clock_(model_checking)"},{"title":"Region (model checking) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Region_(model_checking)"},{"title":"Kripke structure (model checking) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kripke_structure_(model_checking)"},{"title":"Category:Model checking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Model_checking"},{"title":"Principles of Model Checking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Principles_of_Model_Checking"},{"title":"BLAST model checker - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BLAST_model_checker"},{"title":"TAPAs model checker - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TAPAs_model_checker"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of model checking:

## Definition

Model checking or property checking is a method for checking whether a finite-state model of a system meets a given specification (also known as correctness).(no content)This is typically associated with hardware or software systems, where the specification contains liveness requirements (such as avoidance of livelock) as well as safety requirements (such as avoidance of states representing a system crash).

## How It Works

Both the model of the system and its specification are formulated in some precise mathematical language. To this end, the problem is formulated as a task in logic, namely to check whether a structure satisfies a given logical formula.

## Applications

Model checking is most often applied to hardware designs. However, for software, because of undecidability the approach cannot be fully algorithmic, apply to all systems, and always give an answer; in the general case, it may fail to prove or disprove a given property.

## Historical Development

Model checking began with the pioneering work of E. M. Clarke, E. A. Emerson, by J. P. Queille, and J. Sifakis. Clarke, Emerson, and Sifakis shared the 2007 Turing Award for their seminal work founding and developing the field of model checking.

## Key Challenges

Model-checking tools face a combinatorial blow up of the state-space, commonly known as the state explosion problem, that must be addressed to solve most real-world problems.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Formal system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_system"},{"title":"Logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logic"},{"title":"Category:Systems of formal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Systems_of_formal_logic"},{"title":"Mathematical logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematical_logic"},{"title":"Philosophy of logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philosophy_of_logic"},{"title":"List of formal systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_formal_systems"},{"title":"Category:Formal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Formal_logic"},{"title":"Theory (mathematical logic) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theory_(mathematical_logic)"},{"title":"Logic in computer science - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logic_in_computer_science"},{"title":"Formal semantics (natural language) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_semantics_(natural_language)"}]

I've completed the web search for "Logic formal systems". Here's an overview of what the search returned:

## Key Findings

**Definition and Scope:**
A formal system (or deductive system) is an abstract structure and formalization of an axiomatic system used for deducing, using rules of inference, theorems from axioms.(no content)A formal system of logic consists of a formal language together with a set of axioms and a proof system used to draw inferences from these axioms.

**Components:**
A formal language consists of an alphabet and syntactic rules. The alphabet is the set of basic symbols used in expressions. The syntactic rules determine how these symbols may be arranged to result in well-formed formulas.

**Types of Logic:**
Today, the most commonly used system is classical logic. It consists of propositional logic and first-order logic.(no content)Extended logics accept the basic intuitions behind classical logic and apply it to other fields, such as metaphysics, ethics, and epistemology. Deviant logics, on the other hand, reject certain classical intuitions and provide alternative explanations of the basic laws of logic.

**Historical Development:**
Mathematical logic was developed in 19th century Europe.(no content)David Hilbert instigated a formalist movement called Hilbert's program as a proposed solution to the foundational crisis of mathematics, that was eventually tempered by Gödel's incompleteness theorems.

**Modern Applications:**
Major subareas include model theory, proof theory, set theory, and recursion theory (also known as computability theory).

Web search results for query: "Multi-Agent Systems"

Links: [{"title":"Category:Multi-agent systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Multi-agent_systems"},{"title":"Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Distributed multi-agent reasoning system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_multi-agent_reasoning_system"},{"title":"Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_Agents_and_Multi-Agent_Systems"},{"title":"International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Conference_on_Autonomous_Agents_and_Multiagent_Systems"},{"title":"// - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jason_(multi-agent_systems_development_platform)"},{"title":"Multi-agent reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Java Agent Development Framework - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_Agent_Development_Framework"},{"title":"Consensus dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_dynamics"},{"title":"Distributed artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_artificial_intelligence"}]

## Multi-Agent Systems

A multi-agent system (MAS) is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

### Key Characteristics

Agents in a multi-agent system have important characteristics including autonomy (agents are at least partially independent, self-aware, autonomous) and decentralization (no agent is designated as controlling).(no content)Multi-agent systems can manifest self-organisation as well as self-direction and other control paradigms and related complex behaviors even when the individual strategies of all their agents are simple.

### Components and Types of Agents

Multi-agent systems consist of agents and their environment. Typically multi-agent systems research refers to software agents, but the agents could equally well be robots, humans or human teams.(no content)Agents can be classified into reactive agents (automaton that receives input, processes it and produces an output) and deliberative agents (have an internal view of the environment and are able to follow their own plans).

### Applications

Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.(no content)Consensus dynamics in multi-agent systems has applications in physiological systems, gene regulatory networks, large-scale energy systems, and coordinated control of autonomous vehicle fleets on land, in the air, or in space.

### Recent Developments

With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

Links: [{"title":"Formal verification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_verification"},{"title":"ISP Formal Verification Tool - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISP_Formal_Verification_Tool"},{"title":"Formal methods - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_methods"},{"title":"Verification condition generator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Verification_condition_generator"},{"title":"High-level verification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/High-level_verification"},{"title":"Verification and validation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Verification_and_validation"},{"title":"Compiler correctness - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compiler_correctness"},{"title":"Murφ - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mur%CF%86"},{"title":"Joseph Sifakis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._Sifakis"},{"title":"IBM Israel - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IBM_Haifa_Labs"}]

## Formal Verification - Search Results

Formal verification is the act of proving or disproving the correctness of a system with respect to a certain formal specification or property, using formal methods of mathematics.

### Key Characteristics

The verification of these systems is done by ensuring the existence of a formal proof of a mathematical model of the system.(no content)Examples of mathematical objects used to model systems are: finite-state machines, labelled transition systems, Horn clauses, Petri nets, vector addition systems, timed automata, hybrid automata, process algebra, formal semantics of programming languages such as operational semantics, denotational semantics, axiomatic semantics and Hoare logic.

### Main Approaches

Two primary approaches to formal verification include:

1. **Model Checking**: Model checking involves a systematic and exhaustive exploration of the mathematical model. Such exploration is possible for finite models, but also for some infinite models, where infinite sets of states can be effectively represented finitely by using abstraction or taking advantage of symmetry. Usually, this consists of exploring all states and transitions in the model, by using smart and domain-specific abstraction techniques to consider whole groups of states in a single operation and reduce computing time.

2. **Deductive Verification**: It consists of generating from the system and its specifications (and possibly other annotations) a collection of mathematical proof obligations, the truth of which imply conformance of the system to its specification, and discharging these obligations using either proof assistants (interactive theorem provers) (such as HOL, ACL2, Isabelle, Rocq (previously known as Coq) or PVS), or automatic theorem provers, including in particular satisfiability modulo theories (SMT) solvers.

### Industrial Applications

At present, formal verification is used by most or all leading hardware companies, but its use in the software industry is still languishing.(no content)Formal methods are applied in different areas of hardware and software, including routers, Ethernet switches, routing protocols, security applications, and operating system microkernels such as seL4.

content.content:
Web search results for query: "Formal verification"

Links: [{"title":"Formal verification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_verification"},{"title":"ISP Formal Verification Tool - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISP_Formal_Verification_Tool"},{"title":"Formal methods - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_methods"},{"title":"Verification condition generator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Verification_condition_generator"},{"title":"High-level verification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/High-level_verification"},{"title":"Verification and validation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Verification_and_validation"},{"title":"Compiler correctness - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compiler_correctness"},{"title":"Murφ - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mur%CF%86"},{"title":"Joseph Sifakis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._Sifakis"},{"title":"IBM Israel - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IBM_Haifa_Labs"}]

## Formal Verification - Search Results

Formal verification is the act of proving or disproving the correctness of a system with respect to a certain formal specification or property, using formal methods of mathematics.

### Key Characteristics

The verification of these systems is done by ensuring the existence of a formal proof of a mathematical model of the system.(no content)Examples of mathematical objects used to model systems are: finite-state machines, labelled transition systems, Horn clauses, Petri nets, vector addition systems, timed automata, hybrid automata, process algebra, formal semantics of programming languages such as operational semantics, denotational semantics, axiomatic semantics and Hoare logic.

### Main Approaches

Two primary approaches to formal verification include:

1. **Model Checking**: Model checking involves a systematic and exhaustive exploration of the mathematical model. Such exploration is possible for finite models, but also for some infinite models, where infinite sets of states can be effectively represented finitely by using abstraction or taking advantage of symmetry. Usually, this consists of exploring all states and transitions in the model, by using smart and domain-specific abstraction techniques to consider whole groups of states in a single operation and reduce computing time.

2. **Deductive Verification**: It consists of generating from the system and its specifications (and possibly other annotations) a collection of mathematical proof obligations, the truth of which imply conformance of the system to its specification, and discharging these obligations using either proof assistants (interactive theorem provers) (such as HOL, ACL2, Isabelle, Rocq (previously known as Coq) or PVS), or automatic theorem provers, including in particular satisfiability modulo theories (SMT) solvers.

### Industrial Applications

At present, formal verification is used by most or all leading hardware companies, but its use in the software industry is still languishing.(no content)Formal methods are applied in different areas of hardware and software, including routers, Ethernet switches, routing protocols, security applications, and operating system microkernels such as seL4.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about software frameworks:

## Definition

A software framework is software that provides reusable, generic functionality which developers can extend or customize to create complete solutions.(no content)It offers an abstraction layer over lower-level code and infrastructure, allowing developers to focus on implementing business logic rather than building common functionality from scratch.

## Key Characteristics

A framework is intentionally incomplete scaffolding designed to be completed through its extension points while following specific architectural patterns. A major distinction is that in a framework, the framework controls the flow and calls user code at specific points, often via the Template Method Pattern — unlike libraries where the user code controls the flow.

Frameworks provide pre-implemented functionality (e.g., standard features or workflows) that can be used as-is or customized within a predefined structure.

## Benefits and Drawbacks

A framework is intended to enhance productivity by allowing developers to focus on satisfying business requirements rather than reimplementing generic functionality. However, learning how to use a framework can be substantial, and the intended efficiencies of using the framework may be outweighed by the cost to learn it, especially for a framework that is new to the development staff.

## Examples

Some popular modern frameworks include Electron, a free and open-source software framework designed to create desktop applications using web technologies that are rendered using a version of the Chromium browser engine and a back end using the Node.js runtime environment, and Tauri, an open-source software framework designed to create cross-platform desktop and mobile applications using a web frontend, which functions with a Rust back-end and a JavaScript front-end.
